    Targeting Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor Delta (PPARδ): A Medicinal Chemistry Perspective

    • Tara Man Kadayat
      Tara Man Kadayat

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    One of the three subtypes of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) functioning as a transcription factor is the PPARβ or PPARδ. PPARδ is crucial to pathophysiological processes, including metabolic disorders, liver diseases, and cardiovascular diseases. In the past, the clinical development of PPARδ-selective agonist drugs has been stalled due to potential safety-related issues. Despite the elusiveness of such a drug, efforts continue in developing drugs that target PPARδ due to advances in the knowledge of the PPARδ receptor’s structure and functions. While several preclinical and clinical studies are reported on PPARδ agonists, there is limited data with no clinical evidence available for PPARδ-selective antagonists. In this review, we mainly focus on the challenges of PPARδ selectivity and the medicinal chemistry of most active agonists discovered by different pharmaceutical companies and institutes. With this in mind, we also provide an update on the development status of PPARδ agonists that are undergoing clinical trials and their therapeutic promise for the treatment of various diseases.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are members of the ligand-activated transcription factors of nuclear receptors. Depending on distinct ligand specificity, their physiological roles, and tissue distribution, PPARs are categorized into three isotypes: PPARα, PPARγ, and PPARδ.(1) In particular, PPARδ (delta) (also referred as PPARβ) is one of the three isotypes of the PPAR transcription factor superfamily that are essential in several biological functions. Unlike PPARα and PPARγ, this isoform is ubiquitously expressed. Therefore, its function and application were the least understood among the PPARs in drug discovery chemistry.(2,3) However, after the discovery of high-affinity synthetic PPARδ agonists such as GW0742 and GW501516, several researchers have investigated the role of PPARδ, not only in obesity and diabetes but also in other conditions such as cancer,(4,5) neurological disorder,(6) inflammation,(7,8) dyslipidemia,(9) cardiac disease,(10) and liver disease.(11)
    Some studies have suggested that PPARδ is activated by endogenous polyunsaturated fatty acids, arachidonic acid, 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (15-HETE), and prostacyclin.(12−14) However, the physiological significance of these endogenous PPARδ natural ligands is unknown. A preclinical study by Kurtz et al.(15) revealed that carbaprostacyclin, a semisynthetic analogue of prostacyclin,(16) acts as a PPARδ agonist that prevents the accumulation of excess placental lipids in diabetic rats. Concurrently, Kim et al.(17) identified phosphoiodyn A (Figure 1) from a Korean sponge (Placospongia sp.) as a potent and selective human PPARδ agonist (EC50 of 23.7 nM) with over 200-fold selectivity compared to PPARα and PPARγ. More recently, Zhao et al.(18) identified picrasidine N, a natural dimeric alkaloid obtained from the plant Picrasma quassioides, as a new isotype-selective and gene-selective PPARδ agonist.
    After the first report on synthetic PPARδ agonists in 1997, several research groups have synthesized both PPARδ-selective agonists and antagonists to understand the pharmacology of PPARδ for developing novel therapeutic agents. Some preliminary experimental reports on PPARδ antagonists, such as GSK3787 (Figure 1), have suggested their beneficial effects on cancer and psoriasis.(19−22) To our knowledge, there are only a limited number of studies focused on the discovery of antagonists. Some researchers have speculated the possibility of the development of selective PPARδ antagonists as new drugs for cancer therapy. Unlike PPARδ agonists, no clinical evidence is available for PPARδ antagonists. In this review, we aim to summarize selective PPARδ agonists introduced to date, with particular focus on recent clinical development efforts against various diseases.
    A recent review paper by Takada and Makishima has covered several novel PPARδ-selective agonists that were patented to develop new drugs that can treat metabolic, muscular, vascular, and neuronal diseases.(23) Yet, there is no FDA-approved drug specifically targeting PPARδ. Clinical trials of selective PPARδ agonists, such as MBX-8025/Seladelpar (CymaBay Therapeutics), REN-001 (Reneo Pharmaceuticals), and ASP0367 and ASP1128 (Mitobridge/Astellas Pharma), are underway to make them available for clinical use (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03551522, NCT04024813, NCT03833128, NCT04226274, NCT04184882, and NCT03941483). In this Perspective, we will provide an update on the medicinal chemistry aspects of the most potent and selective PPARδ agonists. We will also provide updates on the efforts made for preclinical and clinical development as potential therapeutic agents, primarily for the treatment of metabolic, liver, and muscular diseases.

    2. Biological Roles of PPARδ

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Upon activation, PPARδ heterodimerizes with the retinoid X receptor (RXR) before binding with the peroxisome proliferator response element (PPRE) region in the DNA of target genes to stimulate or repress gene transcription. A recent study has suggested that interactions between a specific amino acid residue of PPARδ ligand-binding domain and its agonist are key factors that determine the transcriptional activation or repression activity of PPARδ.(24) A recent study(18) showed that unlike GW0742, a synthetic PPARδ agonist that induces the expression of various PPAR target genes, such as PDK4 (pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase 4), ANGPTL4 (angiopoietin like protein 4), ADRP (adipose differentiation-related protein), and CPT1 (carnitine palmytoyltransferase 1), a natural alkaloid called picrasidine N only transactivated the ANGPTL4 gene. The result suggested picrasidine N as a novel and gene-selective PPARδ agonist that can be used to elucidate the function and mechanism of specific PPARδ-regulated gene expressions. In skeletal muscle, GW501516 acts as a key regulator of PPARδ-induced gene expression and promotes energy consumption preference from carbohydrate to lipid as the main energy substrate.(25) Narkar et al.(26) in 2008 described GW501516 as an exercise mimetic drug because GW501516 and exercise training synergistically enhanced oxidative myofibers and running endurance in adult mice by inducing expression of genes linked to muscle remodeling, oxidative metabolism, and mitochondrial biogenesis. GW501516 has been sold as “Cardarine” through black market channels and was reportedly misused by athletes and fitness trainers for weight loss and performance enhancement.(27) Therefore, the World Anti-Doping Agency added GW501516 and related PPARδ agonists to its list of prohibited substances in 2009.(28) Several studies have demonstrated that PPARδ has a wide variety of biological effects. Figure 2 summarizes a schematic summary of PPARδ activation’s effects on various diseases.

    2.1. PPARδ in Metabolic Disorders

    Over the last two decades, several reports have revealed that PPARδ is crucial in regulating lipid metabolism and glucose homeostasis. Its activation is especially helpful in preventing metabolic disorders such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and dyslipidemia.(29−32)Figure 2 illustrates the several underlying mechanisms of PPARδ agonists in preventing obesity. The activation of PPARδ induces fat burning in skeletal muscles by either enhancing fatty acid oxidation or increasing the oxidative metabolism of different muscle fiber types.(33,34) Sodhi et al.(35) demonstrated that PPARδ activation plays a role in suppressing angiotensin II-mediated lipid accumulation and adipocyte growth, suggesting the potential therapeutic benefit of PPARδ agonist in obesity. In contrast, some previous reports suggested that PPARδ activation may play role in adipocyte differentiation and lipid accumulation.(36,37) These critical findings could be explained by the indirect role of PPARδ in regulating PPARγ expression(26) and how adipocyte differentiation requires cAMP-elevating agents.(27) These findings emphasize the need for highly selective PPARδ agonist in the treatment of obesity.
    PPARδ activation reduces the amount of very-low-density lipoprotein-triglyceride (VLDL-TG) by increasing hepatic fatty acid oxidation.(9) Oliver et al.(38) demonstrated that PPARδ agonists increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL)-cholesterol levels by increasing the number of HDL’s hepatic apolipoproteins, namely ApoA1 and ApoA2. The activation of PPARδ plays a role in reducing low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels by decreasing intestinal cholesterol absorption.(39)
    Lee et al.(40) even reported that PPARδ activation improves glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity. In skeletal muscles, PPARδ activation induces fatty acid oxidation and glucose uptake, and by interacting with AMPK (5′ adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase), it also prevents insulin resistance caused by endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress.(41−43) In adipocytes and hepatocytes, PPARδ activation is responsible for preventing IL-6-induced insulin resistance by inhibiting the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) pathway.(44) Kim et al. recently determined that the GW501516 inhibited TNF-α-induced decrease of adiponectin expression and enhanced insulin sensitivity by increasing insulin receptor expression.(45) It enhanced mitochondrial oxidation in pancreatic β-cells that increases glucose-stimulated insulin secretion.(46) Yang et al.(47) even indicated that PPARδ activation could upregulate glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) expression, inhibiting the palmitate-induced apoptosis of pancreatic β-cells. More recently, Doktorova et al.(48) suggested that the activation of intestinal PPARδ prevents diet-induced obesity, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance. Despite many preclinical and clinical development efforts, there are no PPARδ agonists clinically available as drugs for metabolic disorders as of this writing.

    2.2. PPARδ in Liver Diseases

    In the liver, PPARδ is expressed in hepatocytes, hepatic stellate cells, and Kupffer cells.(11) Besides the regulation of glucose and fatty acid metabolism, studies have suggested that PPARδ also has a vital role in controlling different types of liver diseases. These types include nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), liver fibrosis, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and primary biliary cholangitis/cirrhosis (PBC).(49−51) PPARδ activation was found to improve inflammation and hepatic steatosis by inhibiting inflammatory responses and reducing the levels of IL-1β in a mouse model.(9,52) Lee et al. even suggested that PPARδ agonists suppress the inflammatory cytokines TNF-α and MCP-1, proving beneficial in NAFLD.(53) A more recent study by Tong et al.(54) suggested that PPARδ activation prevents hepatic steatosis by autophagy formation, promoted by AMPK, and suppressed by the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway. Furthermore, PPARδ agonist GW0742 activation reduces CCl4-induced hepatotoxicity through the downregulation of proinflammatory genes.(55) A study by Iwaisako et al.(11) demonstrated the beneficial effects of a selective PPARδ agonist KD-3010 in animal models of liver injury and fibrosis. Notably, the same study indicated that GW501516 did not have any beneficial effects on the same experimental animal models. Iwaisako et al.’s study(11) also suggested that PPARδ agonists with distinct pharmacophores could have different effects on pathological conditions due to different factors such as the compound’s potency, pharmacokinetic profile, and specificity for PPARα and PPARγ. Despite several promising studies on PPARδ agonists that have antifibrotic, hepatoprotective, and choleretic effects in a mouse model, none has produced a viable drug for liver disease in the market.(49,50) Recent clinical trials of the selective PPARδ agonist MBX-8025 (Seladelpar) suggested positive aspects in developing new drugs for the treatment of PBC and related liver diseases (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03602560, NCT03551522, and NCT04024813).

    2.3. PPARδ in Cardiovascular Diseases

    PPARδ is one of the key transcription factors maintaining the normal physiology of the heart. Because of its prominent expression level in cardiomyocytes, PPARδ reportedly controls myocardial energy metabolism by regulating fatty acid and glucose utilization as well as lipid metabolism.(56−58) As a protecting factor, PPARδ maintains mitochondrial redox homeostasis, regulates expression levels of endogenous antioxidants, and exerts anti-inflammatory effects.(59−61) In various cardiac pathophysiological conditions (e.g., angiotensin II and TAC-induced left ventricular pressure overload, doxorubicin-induced cardiac cytotoxicity, and STZ-induced diabetic heart), PPARδ levels are found to be downregulated.(62,63) The deletion of PPARδ impairs cardiac dysfunction, cardiac hypertrophy, remodeling, cardiomyopathy, and heart failure.(64,65) Many studies on PPARδ agonists are found to protect from various cardiac disorders such as myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI), reduced infarct size, and fibrotic remodeling.(66,67) PPARδ agonists, such as GW0742, can protect cardiac hypertrophy from postmyocardial infarction.(68) Several reports have also demonstrated that PPARδ signaling is impaired in myocardial ischemia, doxorubicin cardiotoxicity, cardiac hypertrophy, and diabetic cardiomyopathy.(58) Even though further investigations are required to uncover the underlying mechanisms of PPARδ, its crucial role in heart physiology and pathology has attracted interest in developing novel therapeutics to treat cardiovascular disorders.(58)
    Jiang et al. recently reviewed the role of PPARδ activation in managing metabolic hypertension caused by vascular dysfunction and metabolic disturbance.(69) PPARδ is reportedly vital in maintaining these vascular functions: increasing the expression of the vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR), enhancing the proliferation and angiogenesis of endothelial cells, and promoting the vasodilation of vascular endothelial cells. PPARδ even reduces harmful inflammation and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in vascular smooth muscle cells.(70−73) Another study by Zhang et al.(74) recently demonstrated a novel underlying mechanism of GW501516 for preventing vascular disease by increasing DHFR (dihydrofolate reductase) gene expression and activating the BH4 (tetrahydrobiopterin) salvage pathway.

    2.4. PPARδ in Wound Healing and Regeneration

    Magadum et al.(75) recently summarized the role of PPARδ in wound healing and regenerative processes through apoptosis, energy metabolism, inflammation, cell proliferation and differentiation, and angiogenesis. PPARδ activation studies have suggested its vital role in the skin,(59) endothelial tissue,(76) and corneal epithelial(77) wound healing, along with the regeneration of bone(78) and skeletal muscle.(79) Liu et al.(80) indicated that PPARδ upregulates phosphoinositide-dependent kinase 1 (PDK1)/Akt and transcription factor E2f signaling, which control hepatocyte proliferation in regenerating liver. Furthermore, PPARδ activation inhibits fibrosis and apoptosis and promotes angiogenesis and proliferation of cardiomyocytes, thereby enhancing cardiac muscle healing and regeneration.(67,81) From these studies, researchers suggest that the development of PPARδ agonists has excellent therapeutic potential for enhancing regenerative processes.

    2.5. PPARδ in Neurodegenerative Diseases

    PPARδ plays a vital role in neuroprotection, myelination, astroglia differentiation, neurogenesis, and oligodendrocyte differentiation.(82,83) PPARδ activation promotes fatty acid metabolism and antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms in the brain.(82) A study by Blass et al.(84) has highlighted a patent suggesting that PPARδ is essential for normal neurophysiological processes. The study further states that PPARδ could be a promising target for the development of an antidemyelinating drug for multiple sclerosis. Several studies have demonstrated that PPARδ agonist GW0742 provides neuroprotection in a mouse model of Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and multiple sclerosis.(85−87) Dickey et al. from the University of California San Diego demonstrated that KD-3010, a PPARδ-specific agonist, may be valuable for treating neurodegenerative diseases like Huntington’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease.(88,89) Particularly, they reported the basis for the neuroprotective effect of PPARδ by activating autophagy and thereby enhancing oxidative metabolism and promoting protein and mitochondrial quality control.(89) A recent study(90) also indicated that GW501516 inhibits the nucleotide-binding domain and leucine-rich-repeat-protein 3 (NLRP3) inflammasome-mediated neuroinflammation in the 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP)-mouse model of Parkinson’s disease. Despite these studies, more research efforts are needed to develop drugs targeting PPARδ for neurodegenerative diseases.

    2.6. PPARδ in Cancer

    The role of PPARδ in oncology is the most controversial aspect, as several reports regarding its association in tumor suppression and tumor promotion have been discrepant.(4,91−93) Several studies have shown that PPARδ is linked to colon,(48) breast,(94) lung,(95,96) and skin(97) cancers. PPARδ’s association with cancer was first reported with colorectal cancer, and there were several controversial and conflicting reports about the effect of PPARδ activation on colorectal tumors.(13) For instance, Gupta et al.(98) reported that PPARδ activation plays a role in promoting colon cancer, while another report by Marin et al.(99) showed that PPARδ activation inhibits colon carcinogenesis. Likewise, some studies suggested that PPARδ promotes the formation of breast cancer,(94) while a few others demonstrated the suppressive role of PPARδ on breast cancer.(100) Pedchenko et al. reported that PPARδ activation induces proliferative effects on nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC).(95) More specifically, PPARδ showed antiapoptotic and antiproliferative properties through phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt1 and cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) pathways. Montagner et al. reported that PPARδ expression was positively correlated with skin cancer.(97) Zhou et al. recently reported an underlying mechanism of selective PPARδ agonist GW501516 on colorectal cancer, tumor growth, and cancer metabolism.(101) The study’s results show that GW501516 significantly enhanced proinflammatory gene expressions (COX-2, IL-6, IL-8, and MCP-1) in an inflamed colon. Ding et al. also suggested the role of GW501516 in tumor formation, as demonstrated by the GW501516-induced expressions of glucose transporter 1 (Glut1) and solute carrier family 1 member 5 (SLC1A5) in several cancer cell lines, including HeLa and HCT-116.(102) However, because of several controversial reports about its relationship to cancer, further studies are required to better define the role of PPARδ activation in cancer biology.

    2.7. PPARδ in Other Diseases

    Researchers have also investigated PPARδ’s effects on other diseases besides the ones described above. For example, Banno et al. recently highlighted the role of PPARs, including PPARδ, in the pathogenesis of asthma.(103) The study reports that PPARδ agonists show anti-inflammatory activities associated with the pathophysiology of asthma. Some studies have demonstrated in a mouse model that selective PPARδ agonist GW0742 is crucial in protecting lung tissue by inhibiting leukocyte infiltration, the proliferation of pulmonary fibroblast, and LPS-induced neutrophil infiltration into lung tissues.(104−106) Despite these reports on the anti-inflammatory effects of PPARδ agonists, further studies are necessary to establish the role of PPARδ in pulmonary inflammation and identify PPARδ as a therapeutic target for the treatment of asthma. A patent(107) filed by researchers from the University of Toledo described cinnamic acid-containing PPARδ agonists as potential therapeutic agents for preventing bone disorders, including osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, and metabolic bone disorders. However, more studies are needed to expand the role of PPARδ agonists in the treatment of bone disorders.
    Downes et al. recently demonstrated the beneficial effects of PPARδ activation in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and acute kidney injury (AKI).(108) MA-0204 (compound 37), a potent and selective PPARδ agonist, increased the transcription of PPARδ target gene PDK4 in the muscles of mice. In DMD patient-derived muscle myoblasts, MA-0204 improved fatty acid oxidation and increased expression of PPARδ target genes PDK4, ANGPTL4, and CPT1a.(109) ASP0367 (MA-0211, structure not disclosed) is currently under phase I clinical trial in pediatric male subjects with DMD (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT04184882). According to the Mitobridge Web site, Bracken et al. reported that MA-0204 also improved mitochondria activity and promoted renal function recovery after AKI.(110) Currently, a peripherally active PPARδ-selective agonist ASP1128 (MA-0217, structure not disclosed) is under phase II clinical study (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03941483) in subjects at risk for AKI following cardiac surgery.

    3. Structural Features of PPARδ

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    All three PPAR isotypes (PPARα, PPARδ, and PPARγ) share a common structural organization. Figure 3A shows a schematic representation of their structural and functional domains. In this structure, there are four functional domains: the N-terminal domain, the DNA-binding domain (DBD), the flexible hinge domain, and the ligand-binding domain (LBD).(111) Generally, the N-terminal region is poorly conserved among the three PPAR isotypes and contains the ligand-independent activation function-1 (AF-1). Following that, the highly conserved DNA-binding domain consists of two zinc finger-like structures, which bind to specific DNA sequences (hormone response elements). Then the flexible hinge region allows the movement of the LBD relative to the DNA-binding domain.(112) LBD contains activation function-2 (AF-2), a ligand-dependent activation domain that plays a vital role in converting PPARs to an active form. PPARα, PPARδ, and PPARγ have 60–70% sequence similarities within their LBDs.(113) LBD is also comprised of a three-layered helix sandwich of 12 α-helices and four β-strands. Four helices (H4, H5, H8, and H9) are sandwiched between helices H1, H3, H7, and H10 (Figure 3B).(114) There are 34 amino acid residues that line the wall of the ligand-binding cavity. Although approximately 80% of these residues are conserved among the three isotypes, small differences in the size and sequence of amino acid residue provide ligand specificity.(115)
    The knowledge of PPARδ agonist interactions with subtype-specific residues in the LBD of the PPARδ receptor has guided the discovery of selective PPARδ agonists. There are several reports on crystallographic studies exploring the binding mode of an agonist with the LBD of the PPARδ receptor.(114,116−118) The basic structure of a PPARδ agonist consists of a head, a linker, and a tail, as illustrated in Figure 3C by GW501516, the first PPARδ selective agonist in clinical trials. Its head usually consists of a carboxylate group and a phenyl ring, the linker consists of a flexible carbon chain and/or heteroatoms/heterocycle, and the tail typically consists of an aromatic or heteroaromatic hydrophobic group. Most importantly, the head contributes to hydrogen bonding interaction in front of the AF-2. The linker is involved in hydrophobic interactions with helix 3, and the tail is arranged within a large cavity of the ligand-binding site through hydrophobic interactions.
    In 1999, Xu et al.(114) reported the cocrystal structure of a high-affinity PPARδ synthetic ligand GW2433 bound to hPPARδ-LBDs. The cocrystal structure indicated that the ligand-binding cavity consists of three arms: arm I, arm II, and arm III. Arm I is mainly framed by polar residues helices H3, H5, H10, H11, and H12. Arm II, which is framed by hydrophobic residues, is located at the “entrance” of the ligand-binding cavity near the β-strands. Arm III is also framed by hydrophobic residues and located at helix H5. The carboxylate moiety of GW2433 (Figure 4A) anchors adjacent to the AF-2 helix at the base of the Y-shaped cavity, forming hydrogen bonds with amino acids H287, H413, and Y437 (arm I; Figure 4B). Generally, the potency of PPAR agonists depends on the bonding of its carboxylate moiety with the phenolic hydroxyl group of Y437. The hydrophobic moiety of GW2433 binds in tail-down (arm II) or tail-up (arm III) configurations.(114,116)
    In 2012, Polikarpov and co-workers demonstrated the X-ray crystal structure of the human PPARδ receptor–GW0742 complex (PDB 3TKM) to demonstrate possible methods for the rational design of PPARδ-selective agonists.(117) The crystal structure of GW0742 (7), with hPPARδ-LBD, showed 29 binding interactions (3 polar and 26 apolar interactions) of GW0742 with amino acid residues in ligand-binding sites of PPARδ (Figure 4C). The polar interactions between the GW0742’s carboxylate group and residues His287, His413, and Tyr437 in arm I are essential for receptor activation. Meanwhile, the nonpolar interactions between the hydrophobic tail of GW0742 and residues Val312 (V) and Ile328 (I) of arm II are crucial for the compound’s PPARδ selectivity
    The following are the residues in contact with GW0742 from each arm. Arm I: of the 12 amino acids, eight residues Phe246 (F), Cys249 (C), His287 (H), Phe291 (F), Ile327 (I), His413 (H), Leu433 (L), and Tyr437 (Y). Arm II: of the 12 amino acids, five residues Val245 (V), Val305 (V), Val312 (V), Leu317 (L), and Ile328 (I). Arm III: of the nine residues, two residues, Thr252 (T) and Leu294 (L) (bold residues, Figure 4C,D). There is a slight difference in residue sequence among the three isotypes. Notably, only the PPARα consists of Tyr314 (Y) compared to histidine residues (δHis287/γHis351), and only the PPARγ consists of Tyr355 (Y) residue compared to phenylalanine residues (αPhe318/δPhe391) at equivalent regions in other isoforms. This information about residue sequence patterns allows researchers to design highly potent and selective receptor ligands. A mutational and docking study of amino acids in arm II of hPPARδ compared with equivalent regions of hPPARα and hPPARγ revealed two residues: Val312 (V) and Ile328 (I) of arm II. They are crucial for the PPARδ-selective activation by GW0742 (underscored residues, Figure 4D).(117) Notably, two amino acid residues in arm II of PPARδ, δVal312 (αIle339/γMet376 and δ Ile328 (αMet355/γMet392), have bulkier residues in equivalent regions of PPARα and PPARγ.(117) From this study, Polikarpov and co-workers also indicated that due to bulky amino acid substitution in PPARα and PPARγ, agonists with rigid and large hydrophobic tails and short linkers do not activate these isotypes (Figure 4D). The hydrophobic tail of GW0742 occupies arm II, whereas hydrophobic tails of PPARα and PPARγ-selective agonists simultaneously occupy arms II and III. It was also interesting to note that some amino acid residues in PPARδ have similar-sized residues at equivalent regions of PPARα and PPARγ, δHis287 (αTyr314/γHis351), δPhe291 (αPhe318/γTyr355), δVal245 (αIle272/γIle309), and δVal305 (αVal332/γIle369). Overall, this study deepened our understanding of the molecular basis for designing PPAR-selective agonists.
    Recently, Wu et al. reported a unique synthetic agonist (compound 35) that bound with PPARδ 510-fold more tightly than PPARα and PPARγ.(116) The finding revealed the structural basis for PPARδ high selectivity and how it eventually reduced adverse effects by avoiding the activation of PPARγ-linked genes. Focusing on binding interactions with residues that are only present in PPARδ, Wu et al. designed agonists that best occupy both arms II and III of PPARδ, while improving PPARδ selectivity over the PPARα and γ-receptors. The complex 3D structure of hPPARδ-LBD with compound 35 also indicated that the hexanoic acid moiety in the head of compound 35 anchors adjacent to the AF-2 helix and forms hydrogen bonds with polar residues H287, H413, and Y437 (Figure 4E). A proximal lipophilic group in the tail is positioned mostly in arm II, and a dialkylbenzamide core at the linker lies close to arm III. Wu et al. revealed the role of PPARδ-specific residues and the shape of synthetic agonists for determining PPARδ selectivity. The presence of tryptophan residue (W228) near the H2′–H3 loop, specific to the PPARδ receptor, was presumed to be the structural basis of a potential mechanism for high selectivity.(116) However, the tumorigenesis activity of a PPARδ agonist, such as GW501516, was still unclear as to whether this was due to PPARδ activation or due to the off-target effects of the agonist.

    4. Medicinal Chemistry of Synthetic PPARδ Agonists

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    4.1. Synthetic PPARδ Agonists: Past Approaches and Limitations

    Although the human PPARδ receptor was cloned in 1992, there were no synthetic PPARδ agonists reported until Merck and Company first reported a synthetic PPARδ agonist L-631033 (1, Figure 5) in 1997.(119) Since then, several research groups from pharmaceutical companies and academic institutions have reported selective PPARδ agonists to demonstrate its role in diabetes, obesity, cancer, and other physiological conditions.(4,29−31,91−93) As shown in Figure 3C, all synthetic PPARδ agonists have a common structure: a head, a linker, and a tail.
    PPARδ selectivity over PPARα and PPARγ is one of the key points driving the discovery and development of PPARδ agonists with an improved safety profile. Researchers have utilized computational and medicinal chemistry strategies such as structure-based modification and structure-guided optimization techniques to achieve PPARδ selectivity. Moreover, a new computational method using an in-house machine learning algorithm, Iterative Stochastic Elimination (ISE) has been reported for discovering selective PPARδ agonists.(120−122) The structures of synthetic PPARδ agonists, identified by several groups, are shown in Figures 5–9.

    4.1.1. Merck

    In 1997, researchers from Merck Research Laboratory (New Jersey, USA) first reported the synthetic ligand L-631033 (1, Figure 5), which resembles fatty acids with a phenyl ring in the middle of the chain, as a weak activator of the PPARδ receptor.(119) After two years,(123) the Merck group then identified L-165041 (2) as a more potent PPARδ agonist. L-165041 displayed more than 10-fold selectivity for human PPARδ receptors over other human subtypes, PPARα and PPARγ. An in vivo experiment revealed that L-165041 has no significant effect on lowering plasma glucose or triglycerides in obese, insulin-resistant db/db mice. However, it did affect plasma cholesterol even at a lower dose in the same in vivo experiment.(123,124) Studies by Lim et al. suggested L-165041 as a potential therapeutic agent for controlling pathologic hepatic and cardiovascular conditions.(125,126) Moreover, the Merck group also reported a new series of phenylacetic acid derivatives, with L-165461 (3), L-783483 (4), and L-796449 (5) having a potent agonistic effect on the human PPARδ.(127) These compounds showed significant glucose- and triglyceride-lowering activities in mice. However, the major drawback was that they were active on all of the three human PPAR subtypes.(127)

    4.1.2. GlaxoSmithKline

    In 1997, Brown et al. from Glaxo Wellcome R&D (later merged as GlaxoSmithKline) reported GW2433 (6) as the first high-affinity PPARδ agonist.(128) GW2433 is a trisubstituted urea analogue that incorporated a phenoxyisobutyric acid monomer, generally present in the bezafibrate, a lipid-lowering drug. In 2001, the same group reported on the potent subtype-selective PPARδ agonists GW0742 (7) and GW501516 (8) with a thiazole core. These two compounds demonstrated their efficacy in increasing HDL-cholesterol and insulin sensitivity while decreasing LDL-cholesterol and triglyceride levels in insulin-resistant obese rhesus monkeys. In 2003, GlaxoSmithKline initiated a phase II clinical trial of GW501516 for dyslipidemia (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00158899) and was expected to file for FDA approval in 2008. However, the company discontinued the clinical trial of GW501516 in September of 2007 after they observed a rapid induction of cancers in their animal studies.(129−132) Since then, GW501516 and GW0742 have been used as chemical tools for exploring the structural and rational design of new potent and selective PPARδ agonists.(116,117) Researchers have also used the two compounds to demonstrate the role of PPARδ in different pathophysiological conditions, including atherosclerosis, hypertension, inflammation, and kidney disease.(69,133,134) However, there have been no further reports on their clinical trials as of this writing.

    4.1.3. Bayer

    In 2005, Weigand et al.(135) from Bayer Health Care reported the synthesis of a new, potent, and selective PPARδ agonist (9) derived as a hybrid structure of GW501516 and compound A (a selective PPARα agonist). Preliminary in vitro studies suggested that 9 may have favorable pharmacokinetics. Further pharmacological studies of 9 were expected to develop this compound as a potential candidate for the treatment of obesity, atherosclerosis, and dyslipidemia.(135) However, there are no recent updates on compound 9.

    4.1.4. Novartis

    In 2006, Epple et al. from the Novartis Research team(136) identified Y-shaped 1,3,5-substituted aryl derivative (10) as a highly potent and selective PPARδ agonist, grounded on structure-based drug design using the Y-shaped GW2433 (6) (Figure 6). Compound 10 also showed a favorable pharmacokinetic profile. From the docking results of compound B (an isoxazole group containing PPAR pan agonist) and GW2433, the same group identified compound 11,(137) a novel trisubstituted isoxazole, as a potent and selective PPARδ agonist. It is notable that unlike other reported PPARδ agonists, compound 11 does not contain a flexible linker between the hydrophobic tail and the functional head. In 2009, Epple et al.(138) identified the bisaryl-substituted thiazole core containing compound 12 using the structural optimization of compound 10 and GW501516. Compound 12 was notable for showing excellent pharmacokinetic properties. They demonstrated that compound 12 plays an essential role in regulating genes involved in energy homeostasis.(138) However, our search revealed that no further reports are available on compound 12.

    4.1.5. Novo Nordisk

    A group of Novo Nordisk researchers was also involved in developing selective PPARδ agonists. In 2007, Havranek(139) reported a selective and potent alkynylallylic moiety containing Y-shaped PPARδ agonist (13) using the structural combination of compound 10 and a PPAR pan agonist (compound C). Per et al. described the synthesis of the sodium salt of morpholine containing alkynylallylic phenoxy acetic acid as a selective PPARδ agonist (14; NN-0606) for the treatment of metabolic disorders.(140) The phase I clinical trial of NN-0606 was discontinued, reportedly for strategic reasons.(141) However, NN-0606 (now licensed by Reneo Pharmaceuticals as REN-001) has found its way into clinical trials once more in the hopes of developing treatments for rare diseases, including primary mitochondrial myopathy (PMM), fatty acid oxidation disorders (FAOD), and McArdle diseases.(142)

    4.1.6. Johnson & Johnson

    In 2007, Zhang et al.(143) from Johnson & Johnson reported a novel series of Y-shaped alkylthiophenoxyacetic acids from the structural modification of GW501516 (8) and L-165041 (2). Most of the synthesized compounds showed a highly potent and PPARδ-specific agonistic activity as potential agents for the treatment of dyslipidemia, obesity, and diabetes. From the structure–activity relationship (SAR) study, Zhang et al. demonstrated that the chirality at the Y-intersection and the length of the side arm and the backbone are important for PPARδ agonist activity. Compound 15 had potent activity (EC50 = 0.03 nM) and showed a favorable pharmacokinetic profile.(143) Notably, MBX-8025 (16, also known as Seladelpar) was first reported by Johnson & Johnson in 2007 as a selective and potent PPARδ agonist. However, it was originally discovered by Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceuticals (a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson).(143) In 2009, the same group reported a di-n-propyl substituted compound 17 as the most potent (EC50 = 8.6 nM) PPARδ-specific agonist with a favorable pharmacokinetic profile.(144) Shen et al. identified thiadiazole compound 18, based on structure modification of GW501516, as a potent and selective PPARδ agonist.(145) However, none of the compounds have seen further reports on their development by Johnson & Johnson except for MBX-8025. MBX-8025 is now under clinical development by CymaBay Therapeutics for liver diseases, including nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and primary biliary cholangitis (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03551522 and NCT03602560).

    4.1.7. Pfizer

    In 2007, researchers from Pfizer Global R&D (Michigan, USA) reported the synthesis of benzofuran, benzothiophene, indole, and benzyloxybenzyl-based compounds as potential agents for the treatment of dyslipidemia (Figure 7).(146,147) From the SAR study, they identified benzyloxybenzyl-based compound 19, which showed more than 1000-fold selectivity of PPARδ over PPARα with an EC50 of 70 nM.(146) In another report, the group designed a series of new compounds with steric crowding around the acidic part. They identified benzothiophene-based compound 20 (EC50 = 14.7 nM) and indole-based compound 21 (EC50 = 4 nM), suggesting that they could be used as chemical tools for elucidating the biological functions of PPARδ.(147)

    4.1.8. Nippon Chemiphar

    In 2011, Sakuma et al.(148) from Nippon Chemiphar Co. Ltd. reported a new and unique benzisoxazole ring containing compound 22 as a potent PPARδ selective agonist. Compound 22 showed a strong stimulatory effect on the differentiation of oligodendrocyte in vitro, thereby confirming the potential for the development of an effective drug that could alleviate demyelinating disorders. In May 2017, Hirai et al. from Nippon Chemiphar reported the effects of NCP-1046 (structure not disclosed), a novel PPARδ agonist for wound healing.(149) NCP-1046 showed an approximately 1000-fold selectivity for human PPARδ over PPARα and PPARγ in in vitro PPAR transactivation assays. Notably, in a rat pressure ulcer model, a significant decrease in wound closure time was reported in 0.005% NCP-1046 ointment-treated mice group compared to their vehicle-treated mice when treated topically for 5 days. Moreover, a dose of 0.05% NCP-1046 ointment resulted in significantly enhanced wound healing in diabetic mice models. Although there is no updated data on NCP-1046, that study suggests that NCP-1046 might be effective in low doses for chronic wounds.(149)

    4.1.9. AstraZeneca

    In 2011, researchers from AstraZeneca reported the synthesis of tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives from the structural basis of compound 9 (developed by Bayer) as selective PPARδ agonists for metabolic disorders, including dyslipidemia, diabetes, obesity, and atherosclerosis.(150) Among those synthesized compounds, 23 exhibited highly selective and potent agonist activity at PPARδ (EC50 = 5 nM). The same group reported further optimization leading to the discovery of the most potent and selective PPARδ agonist, compound 24 (EC50 = 3 nM) from the prepared new series of 8-oxybenz[c]azepine derivatives.(120) However, since then, no further reports on their developments have been published by AstraZeneca as of this writing, suggesting that the programs have been discontinued.

    4.1.10. Kalypsys

    Researchers from Kalypsys Inc. reported the synthesis of a series of aryl sulfonamide, sulfonyl, and indole derivatives as potential PPARδ-selective agonists for the treatment of metabolic disorders.(151,152) Guha et al. reported that KD-3010 (compound 25), a highly selective and potent PPARδ agonist with a unique piperazine sulfonyl core, exhibits beneficial effects for the treatment of metabolic disease and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).(153,154) Recent studies by Dickey et al. demonstrated KD-3010’s value in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease.(88,89)

    4.1.11. Orléans, Tokyo, Pennsylvania, Seoul National, and Hebrew University of Jerusalem

    Besides pharmaceutical companies, a few universities have reported potent and selective PPARδ agonists (Figure 8). In 2006, Basséne et al. from the Université d’Orléans identified phenoxyacetic acid compound 26, based on the structure of L-165041 (2), as a potent and selective PPARδ agonist.(155) The following year, Kasuga et al.(156) from the University of Tokyo reported the synthesis of a series of 3-(4-alkoxyphenyl)propanoic acid derivatives based on the structure of TIPP-401 (a PPAR α/δ dual agonist). From SAR studies, the group identified compound 27 (TIPP-204) with an n-butoxy group exhibiting extremely potent and selective PPARδ transactivation activity, better than and more distinct from GW501516. The structure of PPARδ LBD in complex with compound 27 has been reported to determine PPARδ-specific binding modes.(157)
    Researchers from Pennsylvania State University described the role of PPARδ receptor in cell proliferation and cancer.(93,158−160) In February 2010, Genovese et al. reported a natural propenoic acid derivative, 4′-geranyloxyferulic acid (28), that activated PPARδ and inhibited the cell proliferation of a human skin cancer cell line.(161) In the same year, a group of researchers from Pennsylvania State University and Penn State Hershey Cancer Institute reported an efficient synthesis of a novel PPARδ agonist (29) as a selenium analogue of GW501516 with potential anticancer properties.(162)
    In 2010, Kang’s group from the Seoul National University (SNU) in Korea, reported a synthesis and in vivo antiatherogenic activity of a series of selenium-containing isosteres of GW501516.(163) Among these compounds, 29 is notable for showing potent and selective PPARδ agonist activity (EC50 = 0.9 nM). From the results of the in vivo experiment in atherosclerosis mouse models, compound 29 was considered as a potential agent for the treatment of atherosclerosis. In 2012, Ham et al.(164) reported a synthesis of novel Y-shaped PPARδ-selective agonists by substituting alkyl or aryl groups at the α-position of sulfide. Compounds 30, 31, and 32 exhibited highly potent and selective PPARδ agonistic activity and were proposed as safer potential candidates for the treatment of obesity.
    In 2019, Da’adoosh et al. from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem(122) reported the discovery of novel hit and lead molecules using a new structure-based computational tool. They applied a combination of two computational methods: docking and Iterative Stochastic Elimination (ISE), a machine learning algorithm. From the virtual screening of 1.56 million molecules applying ISE, followed by docking to the PPARδ structure, 306 molecules were selected for in vitro testing. Finally, Da’adoosh et al. discovered 13 compounds, including GNF-0242 (33) and GNF-8065 (34), that showed highly selective agonistic activity for PPARδ with EC50 between 4 and 19 nM.(122)

    4.1.12. Salk Institute

    In 2017, Wu et al. from the Salk Institute for Biological Studies rationally designed and synthesized a new generation of potent and selective PPARδ agonists to improve PPARδ selectivity (Figure 9).(116) On the basis of the skeleton of GW501516, they designed a series of compounds with various substituents to occupy arms I, II, and III for PPARδ selectivity. Compound 35 was identified as the most specific for PPARδ (EC50 = 19.6 nM) compared to PPARα and PPARγ. Unlike GW501516, compound 35 contains a hexanoic acid headgroup, which interacts with the AF-2 region of arm I. The study also revealed a potential mode of action of PPARδ ligand selectivity, which could further contribute to design a safer and more potent PPARδ selective agonist to treat metabolic disorders.

    4.1.13. Mitobridge/Astellas

    Lagu et al.(109,165,166) from Mitobridge, a wholly owned subsidiary of Astellas Pharma, reported several compounds synthesized by the structural modification of benzamide PPARδ agonist 35. The group(165) identified compound 36 as a selective PPARδ agonist with improved pharmacokinetic properties using structure–activity relationships. The in vivo study on gene expression data analysis indicated that compound 36 is safer than GW501516.(166) Lagu et al.(109) also reported another potent and selective PPARδ agonist, MA-0204 (37) by isosteric replacement of the amide group with an imidazole ring. Furthermore, in vitro and in vivo assays in mice and rats indicated that compound 37 has a favorable pharmacokinetic profile, suggesting that the compound is a potential agent for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). A recent joint patent by researchers from Mitobridge and Salk Institute described a new series of imidazole containing selective PPARδ agonists (including 37) for potential use in the treatment of several diseases, such as muscular diseases, renal diseases, metabolic diseases, and demyelinating diseases.(108) A more recent study by Lagu et al. addressed a cardiac safety concern for compound 37 by synthesizing new compounds with minimal hERG inhibitory activity. New compounds were synthesized by modifying the basicity of the imidazole core of compound 37.(167)

    4.1.14. DGMIF/SNU

    Our group at Daegu-Gyeongbuk Medical Innovation Foundation (DGMIF) has also been in search of new, selective, and potent PPARδ agonists. We have reported the design and synthesis of a new series of Y-shaped biaryl PPARδ agonists in collaboration with Kang’s group at SNU. We identified compound 38 as a highly potent and selective PPARδ agonist with an EC50 value of 2.6 nM.(121) From the results of molecular docking studies, in vitro ADME/Tox, and in vivo pharmacokinetic studies, compound 38 demonstrated itself as a promising candidate for the treatment of PPARδ-related diseases. In another study, we reported an enantioselective synthesis of a natural product, pulicatin-inspired, unique methyl-thiazoline-core containing novel compound 39 as a highly potent PPARδ agonist (EC50 = 6.2 nM).(168) Furthermore, we recently reported a simple and efficient synthetic route of a dimethyl-thiazoline-core containing compound 40 as a new scaffold for PPARδ agonist.(169)

    4.2. Structure–Activity Relationships

    Table 1 illustrates the SAR of highly selective, synthetic PPARδ agonists reported by various companies and institutes from 1999 to 2019. One of them, L-165041 (2), has a phenoxyacetic acid group and was identified as the first selective human PPARδ agonist. Another phenylacetic acid derivative, L-783483 (4), with a trifluoromethyl benzoisoxazole group at the tail, exhibited better selectivity than L-165041.(123,170) A phenoxyacetic acid derivative GW501516 (8) with a thiazole core at the linker showed enhanced PPARδ agonistic activity (EC50 = 1 nM) and selectivity over 1100-fold against PPARα and 850-fold PPARγ in a cell-based transactivation assay. It is interesting to note that the addition of a fluorine substituent at the ortho-position to the CF3 group (7, GW0742) showed similar potency but better selectivity compared to 8.(171) Notably, many reports have demonstrated the discovery of selective PPARδ agonists through a modification of sides or positions of the head, the linker, or the tail of GW501516.(138,143,163,172) The phenoxyacetic acid compound 9, synthesized through the structural modification of GW501516’s linker and tail, also improved PPARδ selectivity (EC50 = 3 nM) over other subtypes (EC50 = >10000 nM for PPARα and PPARγ).(135) Furthermore, Y-shaped compounds 10 and 11 were synthesized based on the structure of GW2433, also have high PPARδ selectivity confirmed by in vitro transactivation assay.(136,137) The promising activity of compound 11 indicates that a flexible linker may not be needed for PPARδ selectivity. Furthermore, another compound (12), synthesized based on GW501516 by substituting a para-methoxy pyridine group at position 4 of a thiazole ring was also tolerable for selective PPARδ agonistic activity.(138)
    Table 1. In Vitro Potency of Synthetic PPARδ Agonists (nM) on Human PPAR Receptor
    A para-alkylthiophenoxyacetic acid derivative (16; MBX-8025), synthesized based on the structure of GW501516 (8) and L-165041 (2), also showed a potent and selective PPARδ agonistic effect (EC50 = 2 nM) against other subtypes (EC50 = >1000 nM for PPARα and PPARγ).(143,172) MBX-8025 is now under active investigation as a potential therapeutic agent for liver diseases (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03602560, NCT03551522, and NCT04024813)
    Another study showed that steric crowding around the acidic part might improve PPARδ selectivity. Compound 22, with a unique benzisoxazole ring, acted as a potent hPPARδ transactivation activity with an EC50 of 4.5 nM. It showed more than 2000-fold PPARδ selectivity over PPARα and PPARγ.(148) Furthermore, the effects of substituents at anilide moiety was also investigated. Compound 23, with a tetrahydroisoquinoline group based on compound 9, also acted as a potent and selective PPARδ agonist (EC50 = 5, 2500, and 20000 nM for PPARδ, PPARα, and PPARγ, respectively).(150)
    The potent 8-oxybenz[c]azepine compound D (Figure 10A), with a PPARδ EC50 value of 25 nM showed 128-fold selectivity over other subtypes.(120) Further structure-based modification via the introduction of an ethyl group adjacent to the benzazepine nitrogen yielded compound 24, which showed improved activity and PPARδ selectivity with an EC50 value of 3 nM against other subtypes (EC50 = 6000 nM for PPARα and >20000 nM for PPARγ).(120)
    Another study reported the synthesis of phenoxyacetic acid compound 26, modifying the structure of L-165041 (2) to improve its potency and PPARδ selectivity.(155) The study suggested the beneficial effects of a pyridine ring at the tail of the compound. Compound 27 (TIPP-204), synthesized by a small modification at the structure of TIPP-401 (a PPAR α/δ dual agonist), showed potent transactivation activity and PPARδ selectivity. The finding indicated the importance of a butoxy group at the 4-position of the aromatic ring of the head.(156) Compound 27 exhibited more than 250-fold selectivity to the PPARα and over 1200-fold selectivity to PPARγ. Compound 29, synthesized as a selenium analogue of GW501516, showed improved activity and PPARδ selectivity (EC50 = 0.9, >1000, and >1000 nM for PPARδ, PPARα, and PPARγ, respectively) compared to GW501516.(163) Moreover, a Y-shaped PPARδ selective agonist (30) prepared by substituting the halophenyl group at the α-position of the sulfide also exhibited improved activity and PPARδ selectivity. Compound 30 showed strong PPARδ agonistic activity (EC50 = 1.6 nM) with 625- and 6250-fold selectivity over PPARα and PPARγ.(164) Notably, some structurally different novel compounds have been discovered as highly selective PPARδ agonists using ligand-based machine learning and structural modeling techniques. Among these compounds, 33 (GNF-0242), with an amide linker moiety, showed the most selective PPARδ agonist activity (EC50 = 4 nM).(122) Compound 35, synthesized by modifying the head, the tail, and the linker of the GW501516 skeleton, displayed potent and selective transactivation PPARδ (EC50 = 19.6 nM) activity.(116) Further methyl substitution at α- and β- positions of an acidic part of compound 35 led to another selective PPARδ agonist (36) (EC50 = 37 nM), which has an improved pharmacokinetic and safety profile.(165,166) Another highly specific PPARδ (EC50 value of 0.4 nM) agonist, compound 37 (MA-0204), was discovered using the X-ray crystallographic information on 36. A SAR study revealed the importance of the isosteric replacement of linker (amide group) with imidazole moiety, and replacing the 2-furyl group with 4-trifluoromethoxy group for improved PPARδ selectivity over PPARα and PPARγ.(109)
    Finally, on the basis of the structure of GW501516 and compound 35, we recently synthesized and detailed an SAR of Y-shaped biaryl analogues and identified the novel compound (38), with a high transactivation activity (PPARδ EC50 = 2.6 nM) and over 3846-fold selectivity to PPARα and PPARγ.(121) Compound 38 was designed based on the structure of GW501516 by replacing a thiazole group with a phenyl ring (Figure 10B).(121) We found that the introduction of a benzyl group at the α-carbon adjacent to the sulfur is crucial for selectivity. In comparison with GW501516, compound 38 showed enhanced selectivity with more than 5-fold greater PPARδ selectivity. Molecular docking studies of 38 with the crystal structure of PPARδ revealed the phenyl moiety at the α-position of the sulfur group might have contributed for enhanced PPARδ selectivity.(121)

    5. Preclinical and Clinical Development Status

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    On the basis of information in the Cortellis database (Clarivate Analytics), we found that a number of PPARδ agonists reached early stage clinical trials, with some of them under active development.(173) The major PPARδ-selective agonists that reached to clinical trials for metabolic disorders are GW501516 (GlaxoSmithKline),(175) NN-0606 (Novo Nordisk),(141) KD-3010 (Kalypsys),(129) CER-002 (Cerenis Therapeutics/ABIONYX Pharma),(176) and MBX-8025 (Metabolex).(129) However, there are still no PPARδ-targeting drugs in the market.(174) As of this writing, three major companies, CymaBay Therapeutics (MBX-8025), Reneo Pharmaceuticals (REN-001/HPP-593), and Mitobridge/Astellas Pharma (ASP0367 and ASP1128), are actively involved in the clinical development of PPARδ agonists for liver diseases, mitochondrial diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, and acute kidney injury (Table 2, ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03551522, NCT04024813, NCT03602560, NCT03862846, NCT03833128, NCT04226274, NCT04184882, and NCT03941483).
    Table 2. Development Status of PPARδ-Selective Agonists in Clinical Trialsa
    PPARδ agonistdevelopment phasecompanyindicationclinical trial IDstatus
    MBX-8025 (16)phase II (April 2018)CymaBay TherapeuticsNASHNCT03551522discontinued
     phase II (August 2019)CymaBay TherapeuticsPSCNCT04024813discontinued
     phase III (November 2018)CymaBay TherapeuticsPBCNCT03602560on hold
          
    REN-001(14)phase I (May 2019)Reneo PharmaPMMNCT03862846active
     phase I (April 2019)Reneo PharmaFAODNCT03833128active
     phase I (Dec 2019)Reneo PharmaMcArdle diseaseNCT04226274active
           
    ASP0367phase I (January 2020)Mitobridge/Astellas PharmaDMDNCT04184882active
           
    ASP1128phase II (November 2019)Mitobridge/Astellas PharmaAKINCT03941483active
    a

    NASH, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis; PSC, primary sclerosing cholangitis; PBC, primary biliary cholangitis/cirrhosis; PMM, primary mitochondrial myopathy; FAOD, fatty acid oxidation disorders; DMD, duchenne muscular dystrophy; AKI, acute kidney injury. The clinical trials at clinicaltrials.gov are referred to using NCT numbers. Structures of ASP0367 and ASP1128 are not disclosed.

    MBX-8025 (16), a PPARδ agonist, was being developed by Metabolex in collaboration with Ortho-McNeil and Johnson & Johnson for type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia.(129) Since 2015, CymaBay Therapeutics (formerly known as Metabolex) is actively developing MBX-8025 for chronic liver diseases, under license from Ortho-McNeil.(174) MBX-8025 received an orphan drug designation from the US FDA and the European Medicines Agency in November 2016 and September 2017, respectively, for the treatment of PBC.(177,178) CymaBay Therapeutics started a phase II, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03551522) in April 2018 to evaluate the activity of MBX-8025 in subjects with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In November 2018, a 52-week, placebo-controlled, randomized, phase III study (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03602560) began to evaluate the safety and efficacy of MBX-8025 in subjects with PBC and an inadequate response to or intolerance to ursodeoxycholic acid. In August 2019, a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group, phase II trial (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT04024813) of MBX-8025 began in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). However, the company announced in November 2019 the termination of the trial for NASH and PSC due to the initial histological examination of the patient’s liver, where biopsies showed inflammation and erosion of the hepatic parenchyma region, with or without biliary injury observed in the phase IIb study of MBX-8025 in NASH.(179) The company also decided to put the trials for PBC on hold. However, it is hard to say whether the safety issue of MBX-8025 is PPARδ-related or compound-related. Thus, further studies are required for addressing the issue raised in the phase IIb study of MBX-8025 in NASH. While it is interesting to note the GENFIT Biopharmaceutical’s announcement on November 26, 2019, that the Data Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB) has recommended the continuation of GFT-505’s (Elafibranor, a dual agonist of the PPARα and PPARδ isotypes) phase 3 RESOLVE-IT clinical trial in NASH without any modifications.(180) Additionally, it is importnat to note that GFT-505 and MBX-8025 have cleared the two-year carcinogenicity studies in rodents, which suggests that the tumorigenicity of GW501516 may be compound-specific not a PPARδ-specific phenomenon.(181,182)
    High Point Pharmaceuticals, a division of vTv Therapeutics Inc., reported in 2013 the phase I clinical study of HPP-593 (formerly NN-0606, now REN-001) for muscle atrophy (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT01524406).(183) In December 2017, vTv Therapeutics licensed worldwide rights to research, develop, and commercialize REN-001 to Reneo Pharmaceuticals (a clinical-stage pharmaceutical company focused on the development of therapies for patients with mitochondrial genetic diseases).(142) Reneo Pharmaceuticals started an open-label phase I trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability of 12-week treatments with REN-001 in subjects with primary mitochondrial myopathy, PMM (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03862846), and FAOD (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03833128). In September 2019, Reneo Pharmaceuticals announced that the US FDA granted an orphan drug designation to REN-001 for the treatment of FAOD.(184) In addition to PMM and FAOD, Reneo Pharmaceuticals recently initiated a phase I clinical trial of REN-001 to treat McArdle disease (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT04226274). McArdle disease is a rare inherited muscle disorder caused by the inability of the body to break down glycogen in muscle cells.
    Mitobridge (now a subsidiary of Astellas Pharma) is developing ASP0367 (structure not disclosed) as an oral formulation for the potential treatment of mitochondrial diseases, including Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Astellas Pharma initiated a phase I clinical trial of ASP0367 to evaluate its safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy in pediatric male subjects with DMD. This study is expected to end by May 2021 (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT04184882). Astellas Pharma’s other PPARδ-selective agonist ASP1128 (structure not disclosed) is under phase II clinical study (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03941483) to investigate its efficacy, safety, and tolerability in 220 patients at risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) following cardiac surgery. In October 2019, the US FDA granted Fast Track designation to the treatment of patients at increased risk of developing moderate to severe AKI after coronary artery bypass or valve surgery.(185)
    There are continuous efforts that are notable for repurposing PPARδ-selective agonists, such as GW501516, KD-3010, MBX-8025, and NN-0606/REN-001 for novel indications (Table 3). One of the most studied PPARδ agonists was GlaxoSmithKline’s GW501516 (8), which completed a phase II clinical trial for dyslipidemia (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00158899). Unfortunately, it was discontinued in 2007 due to the observation that it rapidly induced cancer in long-term animal toxicity studies.(129,130) Recent study has demonstrated that they could be developed for Parkinson’s disease.(90)
    Table 3. PPARδ-Selective Agonists with Repurposed Indication
    compoundold indicationnew indication
    GW501516 (8)dyslipidemia, type 2 diabetes,(129) and obesity(175) (GlaxoSmithKline)Parkinson’s disease(90) (Nanjing Medical University)
    NN-0606/REN-001 (14)type 2 diabetes(141) (Novo Nordisk)primary mitochondrial myopathy, fatty acid oxidation disorders, and McArdle disease(142) (vTv Therapeutics/Reneo Pharmaceuticals)
    KD-3010 (25)metabolic disorders(129) (Kalypsys)neurodegenerative diseases(88,89) (University of California San Diego)
    MBX-8025 (16)type 2 diabetes, and dyslipidemia(129) (Metabolex)nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and primary biliary cholangitis/cirrhosis(179) (CymaBay Therapeutics)
    Novo Nordisk discontinued its phase I clinical development of NN-0606 (14) for type 2 diabetes due to strategic reasons.(141) The NN-0606 is now being developed by Reneo Pharmaceuticals as REN-001 (14) for PMM, FAOD, and McArdle disease.(142,186) In March 2009, Kalypsys announced the completion of phase I clinical trial of KD-3010 (25) for metabolic disorders and the preparation for phase II trials. However, there has been no further development on KD-3010 since that time. A recent study from the University of California San Diego demonstrated the neuroprotective effect of KD-3010 in neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington’s disease.(89) It is also notable that MBX-8025 (16) was under clinical trial for type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia by Metabolex.(129) CymaBay Therapeutics was putting huge efforts to repurpose MBX-8025 and develop therapeutics for NASH, PSC, and PBC (Table 3). However, the company has recently terminated the phase 2b clinical trial of MBX-8025 in subjects with NASH and the phase 2 study in subjects with PSC. Moreover, the company has decided to halt all studies of MBX-8025 in subjects with PBC.(179)

    6. Perspectives and Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    PPARδ is a ligand-activated transcription factor that plays a central role in regulating various cellular and physiological functions(5,6,58,75) Several reports described the importance of PPARδ activation in various diseases such as metabolic disorder, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and neurological disease. However, there is still a need for detailed studies to understand the molecular mechanism of PPARδ functions. Moreover, pathophysiological functions of PPARδ in response to endogenous PPARδ ligands, and other nuclear receptors remains unclear.(58) A recent study on the high-resolution protein X-ray crystallographic structure of highly selective PPARδ agonists cocrystallized with hPPARδ LBDs has advanced our understanding of the interactions between the subtype-specific amino acid residues in the ligand-binding pocket of the PPARδ and its agonists.(116) Some reports on PPARδ activation, especially to cancer initiation and progression, have influenced studies to explore how PPARδ antagonists can function in cancer prevention.(21) Despite that, the medicinal chemistry perspective of PPARδ agonist studies is continuously growing, with several promising reports. Pharmaceutical companies and research institutes have utilized various techniques for the discovery and optimization of PPARδ agonists concerning potency and selectivity. Several computational approaches, including a recently developed computational method using an in-house machine learning algorithm, Iterative Stochastic Elimination (ISE), have been reported to be essential for designing novel and selective PPARδ agonists.(122) Therefore, in this review, we focused on studies tackling the discovery and structure–activity relationships of the most promising active PPARδ synthetic agonists discovered within the last two decades.
    Although there are no FDA-approved drugs that specifically target PPARδ, several clinical trials that investigate the safety and efficacy of selective PPARδ agonists have been performed, while some issues needed to be addressed carefully (ClinicalTrials.gov identifiers NCT03551522, NCT04024813, NCT03602560, NCT03862846, NCT03833128, NCT04226274, NCT04184882, and NCT03941483). One of the major issues is the safety profile of PPARδ agonists, which was called into question after researchers observed how GW501516 induced cancer in multiple organs in long-term animal toxicological studies.(131,132) Interestingly, reports showing the clearance of two-year carcinogenicity studies in rodents by MBX-8025 and GFT-505 suggest that the tumorigenicity of GW501516 may be a compound-specific not PPARδ-specific phenomenon.(181,182) However, the use of GW501516 did not promote tumor development in early human studies performed in 12 weeks (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00388180).(187) The long-term effects of GW501516 in humans are still unknown. In order to address the issue of tumorigenesis of PPARδ agonists, a long-term studies of one or more PPARδ agonists in human will be necessary. Controversies surrounding the role of PPARδ in tumor prevention and tumor promotion in animal studies should be addressed by cell-type-specific or tissue-specific studies with selective PPARδ agonists and antagonists. The reason for this research approach is because PPARδ differently regulates gene expression in rodent and human cells.(188,189) Efforts to produce PPARδ-specific drugs must improve its isotype selectivity to avoid unwanted off-target side effects, which were observed due to PPARα and PPARγ activation.(190,191)
    In conclusion, several preclinical and clinical studies demonstrated that PPARδ activation is an attractive therapeutic strategy for the prevention and treatment of various diseases, including metabolic disorder, liver disease, and muscular disease. However, due to the ubiquitous expression of PPARδ, careful studies on tissue-targeted drug delivery are needed to prevent these drugs from posing certain health risks on humans. Despite several obstacles regarding the development of drugs that specifically target PPARδ, recent reports on the clinical development of REN-001, ASP0367, ASP1128, and MBX-8025 have bolstered the efforts of pharmaceutical scientists attempting to bring PPARδ-selective agonists into the market. Collectively, this perspective will provide insight and guidance for the future design and development of drugs selectively targeting PPARδ.
